title: 110_hr6422
content: The "Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008" allows small businesses to receive a refundable credit for providing health care coverage to employees. This amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 aims to support small businesses in offering health care benefits to their employees. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 provides a tax credit for eligible small businesses that offer qualified health care coverage to employees, spouses, and dependents. The credit amount is based on the number of eligible employees covered, with percentages ranging from 50% to 15%. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 offers a tax credit to eligible small businesses with 50 or fewer employees and gross receipts not exceeding $10,000,000 in the preceding taxable year. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 provides tax credits to eligible small businesses with specific employee and revenue criteria. The Act outlines requirements for offering qualified health coverage to eligible employees annually. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 provides tax credits to eligible small businesses meeting specific employee and revenue criteria. The Act requires offering qualified health coverage to eligible employees annually, with exceptions for businesses not in existence or experiencing a decline in gross receipts. Additionally, a taxpayer must meet a minimum employer payment of at least 65 percent. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 offers tax credits to eligible small businesses that provide qualified health coverage to employees. Eligible employees are those not covered by certain health plans and not part-time or seasonal employees. Qualified health coverage must be substantially equivalent to coverage provided under specific laws. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 provides tax credits to eligible small businesses offering qualified health coverage to employees. Special rules apply, including treatment of predecessors, controlled groups, mergers and acquisitions, and inclusion of self-employed individuals as employees. Amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements are exempt from consideration. The Small Business Health Care Relief Act of 2008 provides tax credits to eligible small businesses offering qualified health coverage to employees. A new subsection (h) is added regarding credit for small business health insurance expenses, disallowing deductions for expenses already accounted for in the credit calculation under section 36. Technical amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
